location.address: Parassinikadavu Muthappan Temple, Parassinikadavu, Kannur District, Kerala, India

history.short_description: A unique temple in Kerala where Theyyam is performed daily as a form of worship to Lord Muthappan.
history.detailed: Parassinikadavu Muthappan Temple is dedicated to Sree Muthappan, a revered folk deity of North Kerala who represents a blend of Lord Shiva and Lord Vishnu. The temple is distinctive because it follows traditions deeply rooted in Theyyam worship — a ritual art form combining dance, folklore, and devotion. According to legend, Muthappan appeared as a divine hunter who blessed people with food and protection. The temple practices include offering toddy, fish, and meat — uncommon in typical Hindu temples. Theyyam is performed every morning and evening, attracting devotees from across Kerala. The temple sits on the banks of the Valapattanam River, enhancing its spiritual ambiance.

significance.religious: One of Kerala's only temples where Theyyam is part of daily worship.
significance.cultural: Preserves North Kerala's folklore, Theyyam traditions, and unique rituals.
significance.unique_practices: Offerings include toddy, fish, meat — symbolizing equality and inclusiveness.
significance.tourism: Major pilgrimage and cultural attraction in Kannur.

timings.note: Evening Theyyam is the main attraction.

warnings: Photography not allowed inside during rituals
Crowds may be heavy during festival months

best_time_to_visit: Early morning or evening Theyyam sessions

tips_from_visitors: Arrive early to get a good view of the Theyyam.
Carry water; temple surroundings can get hot.
Avoid taking photos during rituals to respect temple rules.
